reviewText:
Sadly, as it stands now I can’t recommend getting this version of FF5. I’d like to, as I quite enjoy FF5 and I was hoping for a nice updated version, but this has too many issues to make it worth your while. It isn’t that it is a mobile port, but a bad mobile port. It just does not look or perform that well on the PC. It isn’t awful, but I just don’t feel like it really justifies purchasing the “update” in this state.

To break down specifics:

The Good:
--Nice updated sprites.
--Supports keyboard and controller and does a decent job on both, they can both be fully remapped.
--More features than the Super Famicom/PSX version.

The Mediocre:
--No music remaster. The music is just a recorded version of the SPC700 soundtrack. They didn’t redo it using modern samples or a live orchestra.
--Character portraits look almost nothing like their in game sprites.

The Bad:
--Very obvious tile seams. The tile graphics were updated along with everything else, but they do not tile smoothly. You can see really, really, obvious seams between most tiles on the map.
--Wonky fonts. The fonts are not anti-aliased for whatever reason, and they don’t line up well, so they look strange/jerky.
--Problematic fullscreen support. On the system I tested it on, which is Windows 10 with a GeForce, it won’t go fullscreen. The game’s GL plugin NeHe GL says the fullscreen mode isn’t supported, no matter what that mode is, despite fullscreen working fine in other titles. Also, this means it uses OpenGL despite listing DX10 as the requirement.
--Looks like it only runs at 30fps. I haven’t put a counter on it to confirm, but it is far too jerky when scrolling for a nice 60fps game.

It just seems really half-baked. It isn’t awful. If you want to play FF5 on your PC it’ll do the trick, but it is not a very competent port at this point. It looks like they just grabbed the mobile code and did the bare minimum to make it run on Windows. I’d give it a miss, personally.

To preface this review: I would recommend Final Fantasy V as a game in its own right any day of the week. While the plot is fairly bare, the characters are cool and the storytelling full of that old-school JRPG charm from the days before everything became about anime and angst. The gameplay sets it as one of the most-solid games in the franchise, both for its dungeon design and combat/skill mechanics. The job system introduced in Final Fantasy III returns here with a flexible cross-job skill system and there's a reason this same set of mechanics would appear in later Square games such as Final Fantasy Tactics, Final Fantasy XI, and Bravely Default.

The reason this review is negative is because of this port in particular. It could not be more obvious that the graphics in this version were designed for a smaller screen--at most HD-or-higher resolutions you can clearly see many of the seams between environment tiles, even in objects such as the skull-and-crossbones banner or the meteorite that crash-lands at the start of the game. The art style used for the character sprites is also weird and jarring when set alongside the animations used in the original FF5, which are almost entirely unchanged here to suit the art change. To cap it off, the jarring dissonance between the Yoshitaka Amano stylized dialogue portraits and characters' sprite designs, which bothered me in the GameBoy Advance version, is more obvious than ever here, in spite of some of the sprite designs having been altered to closer resemble Amano's designs (Galuf's new sprite, for example, has a mustache rather than a beard, and it looks pretty good).

Adding insult to injury, Square once again couldn't be half-arsed to license a decent text font for the game, so as with previous mobile/Steam remakes and ports, the text font is jarringly stock and unstylized against the admittedly nice menu and textbox designs. Between this and the environment tile seam problem, this port of the mobile remake ends up feeling like an incredibly amateurish RPG Maker rebuild of the game.

Thankfully I haven't had any of the screen-tearing issues reported in other reviews and fullscreen mode seems to work just fine. (I am running an NVIDIA GeForce GTX 760, for the record.) I need to play further through this version of the game to be one hundred percent sure, but it at least seems to be solid on a technical level, although it's definitely not playing at 60fps--not that this bothers me in a game where most animations are three frames long at best anyway.

Still, if you're going for the all-in Final Fantasy V experience, you're better off playing the GameBoy Advance version--all of the content with almost none of the problems, and even the text font looks better. I sincerely hope Square pays attention to the negative reception this version has received and smooths out the graphics, but just in case... are any of you intrepid fan-patch-makers up for smoothing out the graphics, maybe?

It really bugs me that so many of the reviews that tell you to not play this game have placed less than an hour into it. I was a big critic of the art style when I saw FFV hit the Steam Store, but since it's my second favorite in the series I wanted a go at it again. I've played the GBA version and an emulated version. Now for some points.

I can say with certainty if you liked FFV, you'll enjoy this adaptation. The artwork is not so bad after all. I have quite enjoyed the animations used. Watching Faris as a Monk using a spell. it just works. It does not feel odd or out of place. It does not feel rushed. Story animations are as funny or sorrowful as they were in the SNES version. The music is not remastered, but that does not take away any points. It's exactly the soundtrack you fell in love with before. And if you're new to FFV, you wont be dissapointed. People in the reviews encourage you to go emulate the game because it's better. At this point, it does not matter what version of the game you play, it's still FFV at it's core.

If you never played FFV, let me just say the job system will sell you on this game. It's fun, addicting and it will push you to mix things up. You unlock a lot of jobs really fast, so you're not stuck being just a simple mage, or just a fighter. Most fights can't just be spammed auto attacks and win, you have to go into them with some thought.

By the end of the day, if you like RPGs, depths, or Final Fantasy games. Get it. Enjoy it, and don't worry about the sub 1 hour reviews throwing a hissy fit.

I think most bases are covered in a lot of the other negative reviews with more views but I will say this, as a long time fan of this franchise Final Fantasy V and VI get no love... and here's just another chalk mark on the black board.

This remake was designed as a quick cash grab for mobile users, it was never Square's intention to port it to consoles / steam and it shows... If the screenshots weren't indication enough, it just looks incredibly shoddy.

I'm among the minority when I say I actually like the character portraits in the dialog boxes because that is the original art design for the game. It was hard to convey that level of detail in pixel form which explains why all the characters have wonky, vibrant colors on their clothing and outrageous hair colors. For example, Terra's hair in Final Fantasy VI isn't even green, it's blonde like Celes' but they had to give the character some kind of uniqueness other than the clothes they wear. Faris should technically look more like Edgar from FFVI as well but then people would get confused.

Until a true 3D remake is realized, this is as good as it's going to get. I can understand where Square was going with this, they wanted to keep the nostalgia alive and honestly, they did a good job on that front. The game literally plays identical to it's Famicom counterpart, the way the characters move, the way the cutscenes play out and of course, the untainted original soundtrack (which I'm actually thankful for because that Walse theme is tight)

Enemy sprites are just insanely well done, the character sprites however are lackluster and that's really a shame considering how much exposure they get so quickly. You literally aquire all 4 party members within a half an hour of gameplay and aquire your first 6 jobs in about an hour. I always remembered switching jobs and looking different was a fun process but considering how tacky the models look in this game, some of the uglier job costumes look even uglier.

If you have an itch to re-play Final Fantasy V, then I would look for a discount, I got mine from GMG. You could also just grab an emulated version because the new jobs (from the GBA version) are garbage and you aquire them way too late in to the game for them to have any kind of relevant impact on your success. I never did like the tacked on crap that artificially extended the games beyond the final dungeons... that stuff is meant for newer age games, not retro stuff, it just doesn't fit and seems really corny. I was never a fan of artifically extending the life of video games any way... like collectables and junk... waste of time.

If you've never played Final Fantasy V in your life, I'd suggest getting it if you REALLY want the experience... however, I would recommened both parties not buy it at full price and try not to support this level of incompetence. We'll never get proper remakes of these games (FFV and VI) if people keep supporting garbage that's just barely passable.

Final Fantasy 5 is often considered one of the Forgotten" Final Fantasies. It wasn't properly released stateside for many years and as a result very few played it compared to the vastly more popular 6 and 7.

5 was a very natural progression of mechanics from 3 and 4. It took the job system from previous games and gave it a new spin. Now in 5 you could switch out your class at will. And you would gain XP in a particular class which would level it up and gain it abilities. Which you could swap in and out with other classes. It's a very modular game that lets you play it in whatever way you could concievably want. Like you can play the game with 4 warriors while still having 4 white mage skills attatched to them. You unlock jobs gradually throughout the game and there are even hidden ones.

The story to 5 feels like a spiritual predecessor to 6. It features things like multiple overworlds and a floating island at one point. But it's in general a more simple and straight forward story. It's a better paced and shorter game overall
date: and one that can appeal to newcomers of the franchise a lot more than some of the more intimidating later entries. The characters in 5 are all likeable and memorable enough. The only real thing I'd say that holds 5 back is the game feels a little samey overtime and I feel like if it lacked it's job system it would've really gotten dull. If you're exclusively playing FF5 for it's story it won't hold your attention as well as 6 and 7 do.\n\nThe port for FF5 on PC is based on the iOS remake that released some time ago. The sprites were completely redrawn alongside the user interface and character portraits. It also includes the additional content that came with the GBA port of FF5. I'd recommend finding a mod that disables the character portraits since they don't match the sprites and were based on the concept art for the game
recommended: so they look very out of place compared to the more modern sprites the game has. It also doesn't feature mouse control so if that's a turn off for you I'd suggest not purchasing this port.\n\nIt's a fine JRPG and if you can find it for a good price I recommend it a great deal."

reviewText:
The definitive version of a fantastic game
Here's a quick list of pros and cons, I'll explain them after.

Pros
Traditional turn based combat using an ATB gauge.
Fantastic battle animations
Charming story
Charming characters
Deep development system that promotes experimentation
Great soundtrack
Plenty of hours of gameplay.
Mixed
Sprites aren't as crisp as the SNES or GBA versions
Grinding makes the game incredibly easy
Lots of RNG. (low steal rates for example)
Cons
Job balance is pretty bad. Certain jobs are useless bar one skill.
Some of the graphics are pretty iffy. You can see where tiles interlock for example.
Post game content is a bit lackluster.

I actually really like FF5, and unless the game was fundamentally altered in a significant way, I simply can't give it a bad review.

Specific to the port, the issues I have are with the sprites not retaining the same charm they had in the original/GBA, and that the graphics are pretty poor in certain areas. The game has an ios interface too, but that doesn't really bother me.

The things I like about the port however, are the revamped battle animations and spell effects. The enemy art is fantastic too.

I'm torn on the graphics because there's pros and cons.


Now in terms of actual gameplay;

It's Final Fantasy V. It has one of the best development systems in any RPG. It has depth and really rewards you experimenting. If you're someone who just wants to optimise right away, you might get a little bit less out of the system because it's pretty easy to break.

Story is charming, but a bit clichéd. The writing is great even if the overall story isn't completely inspired. It gives a good sense of atmosphere.

Characters are pretty generic, but there are some interesting things you learn about them as you go on.

Music is Nobuo at his finest.

If you're a completionist, you might be irritated by the missables, but if you don't really care then it's not so bad. Most powerful equipment is obtainable from a shop later, even if you miss a rare steal.

Speaking of stealing, the RNG in this game can be just awful. Bad enemy spawn rates and bad steal rates can make it a little frustrating at times.

The game is about 40 hours long for the story and 60+ for post game content and grinding.

This is a problematic port, there is no question about that, but I would have to say that, despite its issues, the game is still a lot of fun.  Final Fantasy V has always been a great SNES-era RPG, and that has not changed, even with the problems present in the Steam port.

I think my biggest problem with the port, which is mentioned in most of the other reviews here, is the tile seams are very obviously visible.  This, more than anything else, bothered me, as it just makes certain areas and objects in the game look terrible to the point of distraction.  This also has the result of making certain areas of the game look really bad while your character are in motion.

The character sprites are another issue that a lot of people have with this version.  While I will say they look a lot less distracting in-game than in screen shots, they still take a lot of getting used to.  And even then, something about them just makes them look odd and out of place compared to the look of the rest of the game.  On the flip side, though, the redone enemy sprites look pretty fantastic.

On a positive note, this version of the game contains all of the additional content that was originally added to the Gameboy Advance version, which includes a handful of new jobs, new bosses, and a new post game dungeon.  So, if you've never had access to the GBA version and don't want to play on a mobile device, this a way to be able to experience these additions.

Overall, the game seems to run fine on my PC.  In my 30-plus hours of playtime, I have personally not run into any noticeable bugs or crashes, and load times are non-existent.

Ah, Final Fantasy V.  I still remember playing this game on an SNES emulator way back before the PS1 release.  Back when the main character was given his literal translation name of Butz before being changed to Bartz in later releases.  Quite possibly my favorite game in the entire series, second only to Final Fantasy IX, and only then because I can't choose between them.  I have been looking forward to this release since it appeared in the Upcoming Releases section.  Now, has it been worth the wait?

HELL YES!

This is the same Final Fantasy V I fell in love with so long ago.  The characterization is spot on from what I expected from this release, the graphics are pretty good, sprite work isn't as great as the GBA version, but still good, and the musical score and gameplay are just as great as I remember.  Playing with the job system is just as fun as in previous releases, making your own army of customized fighters with skill sets of your own making.  Want a Knight with the healing abilities of a White Mage?  A Black Mage with the fighting power of a Monk?  A dual-wielding Berserker?  All possible.

Some of the animations and scenes look a little odd now, like when you check in on Faris in Tule.  In the original game, Faris turns her (not a big spoiler) head while sleeping, which makes her hair slip so the characters Butz and Galuf can get a good look at her face, but in this game, she turns completely over onto her front, I think, so the scene makes far less sense.  Whoever did these animations should have paid more attention to the source material, to get not only the animations right, but also the context of each scene.

All in all, a pretty good port, if you ask me.  It's still the game I love in every aspect and I cannot recommend it enough.

reviewText:
An underappreciated classic, Final Fantasy V was originally released in 1992 for the Super Famicom and never saw an official US release until 1999 for the Playstation as part of Final Fantasy Anthology. In 2006, the game was re-released with bonus content for the Gameboy Advance.

What we have here is an enhanced remake of the Gameboy Advance version. The graphics and battle system have changed greatly, as has some of the translation. This can be a good thing or a bad thing. If you're a purist of the original Super Famicom version, then seeing the updates would probably make you feel uneasy and will take some getting used to. If you've never had a chance to play the see in the past, then you won't really care.

The graphics itself are really clean and crisp. They hold the 16-bit charm of yesterday while still presenting itself as something pleasing to the eyes of today. Sure, the portraits of the characters do not look like their sprites, but it's a 16-bit game, so imagination sometimes comes into play. Besides, this is traditional of any Final Fantasy remake in years past  (I'm thinking of Final Fantasy II here). The only issue I had was when the characters move their limbs or do some sort of action on screen. I'm not saying it's bad, but having played the original, seeing these events transpire with updates does cause me to chuckle.

The nostalgia factor kicks in big with the music. I literally have not heard a single change in quality from the original Super Famicom release, as if the music files were taken straight from the original source with no editing whatsoever. As a fan of the original game, this is pleasing to me, but as a fan of modern games, I will say that this is also appreciated. Even without an enhanced music track, the soundtrack is one of Nobuo Uematsu's finest and sounds great even by today's standards. It fits the style of the game itself and the story to go with it.

The story is very well done, albeit typical and to a point even cliché; evil guy threatens the world, four unsuspecting heroes set off on a quest to stop him, yada, yada, yada. There are plenty of twists and turns to keep the averge player involved, and there is also humor splashed in all over the place. There is enough mystery and suspense to make you think and wonder what is coming up next. Everything is presented well overall.

The gameplay, in my honest opinion, still holds up to this day. If you've played any Final Fantasy game, or any RPG in general, then grasping the concept of battle won't be difficult. Battle is simple, exploration is easy, dungeons are challenging, but fair. But what really sets Final Fantasy V apart from the others is the Job System. Yes, a lot of Final Fantasy games instituted a Job System of some sort (in all actuality, this type of system was taken from Final Fantasy III), but this game takes it a step further. As you battle, you gain AP to grow the job you assign your characters. When your Job levels up, you learn an ability (say Black Magic). But, perhaps later you want a character to change their job (we'll use Thief as an example). When you change your job, you can choose one ability that you have previously learned from another job to add it to your arsenal (like Black Magic). So in essence, you will then have a Thief who can cast Black Magic. It doesn't end there and the combinations are near limitless, however, getting everything requires a lot of grinding, something very common in older RPGs.

Overall, this version of the game is just as good as the original. The differences are minor except maybe to the diehard purists out there. This game looks better, but it lacks the nostalgic feel from playing the original. But, if that doesn't bother you, or if you have missed out on this gem in the past, it is worth picking it up and playing for yourself.

The new interface can be a bit weird and intrusive at times, but overall the port is workable enough to play if that makes any sense. Granted if you're concerned with the negatives greatly, a patch will likely be released for this game I imagine. The issues are fairly minor compared to the robust, amazing game it delivers. Additionally, the new menu controls are AMAZING! Being able to instantly exit menus on the fly is an awesome feature, alongside being able to pause the game at ANY instance even during an active battle (in case you have to attend to other business or use the washroom.)

Overall if you're concerned with some of the minor graphical issues and the framerate potentially, I'd say wait for a patch. If you love this game as much as I do however, these issues are fairly minor and do not get in the way of the core game experience, which is delightful. Otherwise I'd recommend playing the GBA port with the enhanced music patch (google it!)

I recommend this game if you don't mind the minor nuanced issues. Lots of people are complaining (and rightfully so if they're that upset) but I can't say the product is unplayably bad because I'd be lying. tl;dr version Far better loadtimes, fewer bugs, and a few QoL advantages over the PS1 port.  But this comes at the cost of inferior graphics on the overworld/dungeons/town sprites. Combat sprites are still okay.

LONG VERSION
This is a PC port of the cellphone version of one of my favorite FF titles.  I'm not here to discuss FF5 as a whole (love the game), but as a voice of rebuttal aganst some reviews I've seen posted for this game.

I have not personally seen the extreme screen tearing or refusal to bootup some users claim.

GAMPLAY PROs
+ 8 way diagonal movement
+ Autobattle is great for grinding or going through easy areas.  (Either all Attack or all repeat last action, based on how you set cursor memory in config)
+ Sprint on world map
+ Automatic quicksaves

GAMEPLAY CONs
- Game runs slow in areas that involve room layouts changing (I've only seen two such rooms, both lategame, as of entering the final main storyline dungeon).
- Cellphone interface means buying multiple items is half as bad/annoying as FF1 NES version.

GRAPHIC PROs
+ Combat sprites have addition animation/poses, based on which job/character it is.

GRAPHIC CONs
- Different character sprites for noncombat (map, story, etc). Initially HATED the new sprites during pre-release screenshots, but they've grown on me after seeing them in motion.
- Portaits, while from the original character designer and decent art on their own, often look almost nothing like the ingame character.
- Very noticibly poor tiling/tile seams in some areas
- Not true fullscreen/widescreen, and supposedly very noticeable on dual monitors.
- A certain portrait and sprite spoils the impact of a famous earlygame plot point.
NOTE: Users have found ways to mod the character portraits.

MISC PROs
Title Menu offers bestiary (filled as you fight) and music player (all unlocked by default).

OTHER Vs GBA
+ Not $40-$80+, and no risk of getting a bootleg or dead save battery.
+ 15 Save slots

OTHER Vs PS1
+ No save menu graphic glitch (PS2), constant freezing (PS3), or insane loadtimes (all)
+ GBA bonus content included

reviewText:
This is one of the worst versions of FFV available.
That said, I will explain exactly why.

I have played through Final Fantasy V twice.  Once on the ps1, once on the GBA.  This Steam port is a port of a port.  The GBA version was the original (not counting the SNES/PS1 versions) and its contents were ported to IOS devices with major graphical changes.  I would call them enhancements, but I find the quality of the enhancements a little subjective.  I personally like them, but not everybody really does.
From the IOS devices, this port sprang up.  And I must say... you're better off just playing this on an iPhone.

For starters, the graphics are significantly worse on PC.  The PC version does use IOS assets, but the tiles are so clearly visible on the overworld that it just breaks any sort of emersion.  I can see where they weren't able to properly adjust the display output of the IOS, therefore you can see each and every single tile on the screen.
Every problem that people would have with this game would probably apply to the IOS version, too.  The character models on the overworld and battle are pretty terrible looking compared to, say, the character models in the psp games (final fantasy I, II, and IV for psp) and they suffer from extreme stiffness for the kind of animation they were trying to achieve.  However, you can control the steam edition with an Xbox controller or a keyboard (HOWEVER, holding the accept button does not auto-select a command).

This isn't a bad game, it's just a bad port.  The gameplay isn't completely butchered.  It's essentially chocked full of the same content you could get in the GBA version, and the GBA version is probably my personal favorite version of the versions I've played thus far.
If you want to play this version, you're not worse off with the IOS version.  And I'm fairly certain the GBA version isn't that hard to find (I'm saying this because I got my GBA copy for $20 at Half-Priced books).  I would only purchase this version of FFV if you have absolutely no other options.

reviewText:
A bit of a preface. The Final Fantasy series was what got me into rpg's some 20 odd years ago. I own multiple copies of the games spread across multiple consoles and I have beaten all of them. While I am not a diehard player I can certainly say that I really love this series. Which is why it pains me to say this but I cannot recommend the Final Fantasy V port.

The positives about the game are that I really like the re-done sprites for the monsters and some of the background sprites for objects and buildings do look nice. You have free movement instead of tile movement and you can quickly quit out of the menus by hitting the menu button. Unfortunately though, those is the only positives.

The first thing bad about this port is what everybody already knows, the character sprites. While I personally don't mind the new sprites, the problem is that they just dont fit in graphically with how the world looks. They look like they were going for a psudo 3D look to them which makes them stick out like a sore thumb against the backgrounds.  Plus their color pallets are exceptionally bright making them stick out even more. It is more or less distracting and constanly pulls me from the experience.

The second bad thing is the profile pics when they talk. While I am all for seeing the original artwork and I actually like how the characters are designed in it, they just dont fit into how the game looks. This is of course is also distracting seeing the clear difference between the simple sprites in the game, and the highly detailed character portraits.

The the third bad thing are the tiling textures, which actually don't tile at all. Around all of the tiles there is an extremely visible seam along all four sides which is, you guessed it, distracting. While moving around you don't really notice it but definately during cutscenes you will. I did read that if you put the game into 720p windowed mode it isnt as bad, but the problem is that it is still there and I want to play my game in fullscreen 1080p.

The fourth and final bad thing is the UI. Being an iOS/Android port the interface was changed to accomondate that. The problem is that SE did nothing to try and get it back to how it was, or done something to remotely change it. Not to mention there is a bug where if you mash the attack button in battle the cursor moves to the row button, wasting a characters turn and weakening them by moving them to the back row. You can move them back to the front but by then you have wasted two turns.

So in the end all we have is a game with a bunch of graphical elements that distract the player from enjoying the game and an uninspired mobile UI. While the game itself is great and it is Final Fantasy V, the lack of art direction really pulls me from the game. I probably won't refund the game as I do wish to own this on PC, but going forth I will definately wait to buy any other games in the series at a steep discount. My only worry is that when FInal Fantasy VI will eventually come to PC, that it will be in the same sad, disappointing shape this game was put in.

reviewText:
The original SNES game had a somewhat broken mechanic. It seemed like the difficulty would waver from insane to nonexistent from area to area for no reason. Armour made little difference to your overall survivability, and some bosses counter so often I found myself having my party attack>heal>attack>heal ad neaseum.

I was hoping that they had fixed this in this re-release.

I am disappointed that the obviously flawed mechanics are still present. I have played up until the void to confirm this and some of the most frustrating gameplay I have ever endured is here.

An example is in the void, there is an enemy that when physically attacked, it vasts protect. This by itself is not bad, but it casts it EVERY time. There is no check to see if it already has this status. If you have dual-wield and hit it with both weapons it casts this twice in succession, dragging out the battle unneccesarily. It is this kind of reliance on enemy counter attacks to drag out battles and increase the difficulty that I find unpalatable. Compounding this is this is many ememies counter even if you miss.

I feel obligated to pointout that you will miss a lot. What is the point of dual wielding weapons if the second hit misses >50% of the time? Enemy attcks seem to miss me so infrequently unless I'm a samurai or using the zephyr cape which doesn't help if you don't have enough to go around...

I like a challenge, but when critical attacks by the enemy are unleashed at any time bacuse instead of using RNG, they were added into the monsters move sets which canbe seen when you manipulate them.

This is overall very disappointing, and I'm sad to say it is just a port of the old game with none of the flaws fixed, with some fancy visual fluff. Unlike with FF IV where they added in augments, or FF VI where there was a good an solid game to start with, this is a poor offering. You can't polish a turd as the expression goes.

Save your money and buy the FF IV or FF VI remakes instead.

I'm going to preface this by summing up the review as succinctly as possible: If you want FF V, go back to the Gameboy Advance or nearly anything before the iOS adaptation. This version is not for you.

Now on to the meat. FF V is a phenomenal game. Beyond amazing in every form, and what I consider to be the pinnacle of the Job system within the FF universe. While this game does still have that, the flaws that are front and center are far too numerous to overlook.

See the short playtime? Yeah, that's because it crashed once and the hiccups began afterwards before I gave up on it. And within those minutes I experienced a number of issues. To begin, it is clear that the game has only been marginally formatted for usage with keyboard input. While most PC gamers today may prefer a controller for their gaming, rebinding keys within FF V to standard WASD movement resulted in a hiccup within a few mere moments: naming input has been bound to the keyboard, ending in a hero named BartzS before I realized that utilizing the Cancel key fixed it or that the Restore Default option was present.

Following that, my eyes locked on the poorest excuse for tiling ever. It's easy to see why the screenshots and preview video show what they do: aspects such as trees or the initial meteorite are so poorly put together that you would expect the quality to come from the very SNES game this originated from. And associated with the poor tiling are the sprites for the characters. While I adore the Amano artwork for the character images, the same love cannot be tied to the characters themselves. Bartz alone consistently looks like a Looney Tunes character trying to intimidate a villain thanks to the chest thrust out and fists at sides" sprite presented here.

I wanted to love this game. I really really did. It's why I shelled out full price instead of waiting for a sale. Final Fantasy V is a glorious game

reviewText:
On the default settings, the frame rate stuttered even on a high end PC (i7 4790K with a GTX 970) and there was screen tearing in full screen mode. I managed to get around the excessive stuttering and screen tearing by changing the VSync settings in the Nvidia control panel, but the game is locked at 30 fps (despite what a few others might claim.) There are also noticeable tile seems in every explorable area. It's unfortunate to see this in a modern PC port of a classic game and these are the kind of issues that are hard to excuse from a professional video game developer.

Despite my complaints, Final Fantasy V is a great game. I ended up enjoying this port about as much as I enjoyed the version for Game Boy Advance, so I've edited my review to recommend the game and reflect that. reviewText:
Well, it's FFV. If you liked old school Final Fantasy games, you will probably like this. It's polished, decently well translated, and moderately difficult, just like the original.

Looks like it has a bit of extra content, though I haven't played far enough to get to it in this version. Not convinced that it adds much to the experience, but Steam cards and achievements are nice if you're into that (I am). There are a few annoying glitches with the ATB menu, but it's not a deal-breaker.

The downsides include the fact that they used a rather half-baked graphics filter to smooth out the pixels, and in fullscreen mode, there is a horrid amount of what looks like screen tearing that could be fixed by using v-sync, which is not an option in the graphics menu.

I didn't like this translation as much as the RPGe one from the late 90s, but it's far, far better than the one from the PSX release of this game. I didn't play the GBA version, so I can't comment on that.

The addition of the Amano concept art to the dialog boxes was a nice touch, even though they look NOTHING at all like the character sprites.

My other complaints with the game were mostly centred around the fact that I forgot how awfully GRINDY this game is (as were most RPGs at the time). Can't really hold that against it though, since it's not a remake, just a rerelease.

Final verdict, if you've already played this on other platforms, you can safely skip it, unless you want to push your nostalgia buttons, otherwise, it does a much better job of that than the butchery that was the FFIV DS port, so recommended. I'd still have preferred a direct port of the original though.
